0.paragraph: The address of the Koch Family Graves Site (H7922-0525) is located at 210 Epping Road, Wollert, Victoria.

page_content='Staff 

Gary Vines 

Dr Samuel Dix 

Role 

Project Director/Excavation Supervisor 

Project Archaeologist/Excavation Supervisor 

1.2  Site location and current condition 

The overarching project area for the Epping Road duplication and upgrade works comprises the same extent 
as Specific Controls Overlay – Schedule 10 (SCO10), which represents the extent of MRPV’s works area. These 
excavation works only occur in a small portion of the project area, which is located at 210 Epping Road, 
Wollert. Currently, the land at 210 Epping Road, Wollert consists of a large residential allotment with a large 
open paddock. The land to the north and east of 210 Epping Road, Wollert has undergone residential 
development, and the property to the south (198 Epping Road, Wollert) is also a large residential allotment 
with a large open paddock. The land to the west of 210 Epping Road, Wollert comprises the road reservation 
for Epping Road and a residential development.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5207_kOCH fAMILY gRAVES sITE (h7922-0252_eXCAVATION rEPORT.pdf'}

page_content='6.  Where no significant feature of deposit is found, or the material has been extensively disturbed, 
mechanical excavation should continue until either potentially significant deposits are again 
identified, or culturally sterile layers are reached. 

7.  Any excavated finds must be collected, recorded and bagged, and exposed archaeological features 

will be recorded in plan, section and photographically.  

8.  The mechanical excavation must continue until a culturally sterile layer has been reached. 
9. 

If burial cuts are uncovered, then a stop works in the area needs to be initiated so the site can be 
cleared by hand by archaeological staff, and Heritage Victoria informed of the discovery 

10.  Following completion of the archaeological monitoring, an excavation report, artefact analysis, and 

artefact conservation plan must be prepared and submitted to Heritage Victoria.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5207_kOCH fAMILY gRAVES sITE (h7922-0252_eXCAVATION rEPORT.pdf'}

1.paragraph: Example: The excavation site is located in Wollert, Victoria, approximately 35 km north of Melbourne's CBD.
source:
page_content='•  Artefact Catalogue in electronic format. 

•  Artefact analysis, including summary tables. 

•  Artefact Conservation Proposal. 

• 

Interpretation to synthesise stratigraphic and artefact analyses and address Research Design. 

•  Assemblage Statement of Significance. 

•  Updated site Statement of Significance. 

•  Management recommendations. 

The excavation report will be prepared in accordance with Heritage Victoria’s Guidelines for Investigating 
Historical Archaeological Artefacts and Sites. 

7.8.1  Artefact conservation specialist 

Conservation can be an on-going process, so discussions with Heritage Victoria will be held once the quantity 
and nature of the recovered artefacts is determined, to work out how long and at what stage conservation 
input is required.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5207_kOCH fAMILY gRAVES sITE (h7922-0252_eXCAVATION rEPORT.pdf'}

page_content='6.  Where no significant feature of deposit is found, or the material has been extensively disturbed, 
mechanical excavation should continue until either potentially significant deposits are again 
identified, or culturally sterile layers are reached. 

7.  Any excavated finds must be collected, recorded and bagged, and exposed archaeological features 

will be recorded in plan, section and photographically.  

8.  The mechanical excavation must continue until a culturally sterile layer has been reached. 
9. 

If burial cuts are uncovered, then a stop works in the area needs to be initiated so the site can be 
cleared by hand by archaeological staff, and Heritage Victoria informed of the discovery 

10.  Following completion of the archaeological monitoring, an excavation report, artefact analysis, and 

artefact conservation plan must be prepared and submitted to Heritage Victoria.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5207_kOCH fAMILY gRAVES sITE (h7922-0252_eXCAVATION rEPORT.pdf'}

page_content='5.  Any visible features were marked on the ground with survey flags and plotted on plans. 
6.  The removal of the topsoil continued progressively over the preliminary excavation area.  
7.  Close monitoring of the excavation was carried out by Gary Vines and Dr Samuel Dix, who also 

inspected the spoil as it was removed. 

8.  Confirmed and potential features that were exposed during the archaeological investigation were 

photographed and mapped.  

© Biosis 2022 – Leaders in Ecology and Heritage Consulting  

15 

 
\x0c9.  Any portable artefacts uncovered were collected and catalogued with their location recorded, 

whether in situ, or within the spoil. 

10.  Excavation continued until the investigation area was stripped of topsoil down to the sterile basal clay 

or bedrock.  

Figure 10  Location of the preliminary excavation area (outlined in pink). Shovel test pit locations 

in red Image sourced from Penzo‐Kajewski, Kurpiel, & Hil (2022)' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5207_kOCH fAMILY gRAVES sITE (h7922-0252_eXCAVATION rEPORT.pdf'}

2.paragraph: The archaeology site is located in Wollert, Victoria.
source:
page_content='•  Artefact Catalogue in electronic format. 

•  Artefact analysis, including summary tables.

• 

Interpretation to synthesise stratigraphic and artefact analyses and address Research Design.

The excavation report will be prepared in accordance with Heritage Victoria’s Guidelines for Investigating

7.8.1  Artefact conservation specialist 

Conservation can be an on-going process, so discussions with Heritage Victoria will be held once the quantity 
and nature of the recovered artefacts is determined, to work out how long and at what stage conservation 
input is required.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5207_kOCH fAMILY gRAVES sITE (h7922-0252_eXCAVATION rEPORT.pdf'}

page_content='6.  Where no significant feature of deposit is found, or the material has been extensively disturbed, 
mechanical excavation should continue until either potentially significant deposits are again 
identified, or culturally sterile layers are reached. 

7.  Any excavated finds must be collected, recorded and bagged, and exposed archaeological features 

will be recorded in plan, section and photographically.  

8.  The mechanical excavation must continue until a culturally sterile layer has been reached. 
9. 

If burial cuts are uncovered, then a stop works in the area needs to be initiated so the site can be 
cleared by hand by archaeological staff, and Heritage Victoria informed of the discovery 

10.  Following completion of the archaeological monitoring, an excavation report, artefact analysis, and 

artefact conservation plan must be prepared and submitted to Heritage Victoria.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5207_kOCH fAMILY gRAVES sITE (h7922-0252_eXCAVATION rEPORT.pdf'}

page_content='If artefacts requiring expert conservation works are identified, an artefact conservation proposal will be 
submitted to Heritage Victoria for approval prior to finalising the project. Heritage Victoria may also request a 
site inspection prior to the completion of the archaeological monitoring, to ensure that works have been 
conducted in accordance with the recommendations. 

If burials or human remains are found, works will cease and the site will be cleaned and defined by hand 
archaeological methods. Heritage Victoria and the Coroner will be notified of discovery. 

7.5  VHI site record update' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5207_kOCH fAMILY gRAVES sITE (h7922-0252_eXCAVATION rEPORT.pdf'}

3.paragraph: The excavation site is located at the corner of Hoddle Street and Queen Street in Collingwood, Victoria.

1.2  Site location and current condition 

The overarching project area for the Epping Road duplication and upgrade works comprises the same extent 
as Specific Controls Overlay – Schedule 10 (SCO10), which represents the extent of MRPV’s works area. These 
excavation works only occur in a small portion of the project area, which is located at 210 Epping Road, 
Wollert. Currently, the land at 210 Epping Road, Wollert consists of a large residential allotment with a large 
open paddock. The land to the north and east of 210 Epping Road, Wollert has undergone residential 
development, and the property to the south (198 Epping Road, Wollert) is also a large residential allotment 
with a large open paddock. The land to the west of 210 Epping Road, Wollert comprises the road reservation 
for Epping Road and a residential development.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5207_kOCH fAMILY gRAVES sITE (h7922-0252_eXCAVATION rEPORT.pdf'}

page_content='6.  Where no significant feature of deposit is found, or the material has been extensively disturbed, 
mechanical excavation should continue until either potentially significant deposits are again 
identified, or culturally sterile layers are reached. 

7.  Any excavated finds must be collected, recorded and bagged, and exposed archaeological features 

will be recorded in plan, section and photographically.  

8.  The mechanical excavation must continue until a culturally sterile layer has been reached. 
9. 

If burial cuts are uncovered, then a stop works in the area needs to be initiated so the site can be 
cleared by hand by archaeological staff, and Heritage Victoria informed of the discovery 

10.  Following completion of the archaeological monitoring, an excavation report, artefact analysis, and 

artefact conservation plan must be prepared and submitted to Heritage Victoria.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5207_kOCH fAMILY gRAVES sITE (h7922-0252_eXCAVATION rEPORT.pdf'}

page_content='10.  Following completion of the archaeological monitoring, an excavation report, artefact analysis, and 

artefact conservation plan must be prepared and submitted to Heritage Victoria. 

11.  The excavation report must be submitted to Heritage Victoria within 12 months of the completion of 

the fieldwork. 

All required workplace health and safety requirements must be adhered to. 

7.4  Hold points for Heritage Victoria inspection 

If graves, human remains, or highly significant archaeological deposits are uncovered, or contaminated or 
dangerous materials are found, then excavation works will cease, and Heritage Victoria will be notified. A 
negotiated strategy for managing the material will be implemented.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5207_kOCH fAMILY gRAVES sITE (h7922-0252_eXCAVATION rEPORT.pdf'}
